docs.title: Welcome!
docs.text:
To the all new Catalyst Studios Guides site! This site will strive to create high quality guides about our packs along with guides on popular mods!

This site is a work-in-progress so there will be missing information and placeholder pages, so please bear with us as we create something great!

Here you'll find guides for our main modpacks such as Little Bit Large!

docs.title: Pack Requirements
docs.text:
• A 3rd-party launcher that will download, install, and run our packs
  • A PC with at least 16gb of RAM
  • A valid Minecraft account

docs.title: Launchers
docs.text:
There are many modded Minecraft launchers available. Here are some popular ones!

  • CurseForge
  • ATLauncher
  • Prism
  • GDLauncher

Catalyst Studios | GitHub | Discord

docs.title: About
docs.text:
Catalyst Studios is a community hub where modpack developers and collaborators can host their projects under one roof while also developing and launching our flagship packs alongside them!

Catalyst Studios | GitHub | Discord

docs.text:
Page under construction!

If you have any questions about contributing to Catalyst Studios, join our Discord!

Catalyst Studios | GitHub | Discord

docs.title: Contributing Guidelines
docs.text:
Guidelines
  1. Do NOT touch mkdocs.yml, pyproject.toml, or workflow files unless given explicit permission AND you know what you're doing.
  2. Do NOT republish Catalyst Guides live on another site.
  3. You should not get any warning or errors when running uv run mkdocs serve | build.
    1. Resolve/get help for any warnings/errors before pushing.
    2. Never disable strict mode for any reason unless you have consulted with the team.
  4. Do NOT delete or drastically change another author's work (unless they're typos or factual errors) without permission from the original author.
  5. No inappropriate content (Profanity, NSFW, Paid content)
    1. Violaters will be banned from the repository.
  6. All guides should follow the Writing Your Guide format.
  7. File and folder names must be lowercase with no spaces. Image files can use camelCase.
  8. Eliminate/minimize external links to content like document, images, or videos.
    1. This helps to keep everything together for offline use.

docs.title: Requirements
docs.text:
• Python 3.1+
  • Github Desktop, Git CLI, or Visual Studio Code
  • UV Package Manager

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text: You will be required to Serve (Live preview) and Build this site.

docs.title: Fork and Enable Workflows
docs.text: Fork the Catalyst Guides repository, then enable GitHub Workflows.

docs.title: Clone main Branch
docs.text:
Now you'll want to Clone your forked repository using your preferred program.

GitHub Desktop

Go to File Clone repository... OR do Ctrl+Shift+O and select your Catalyst Guides fork. (I put _arc for my own sorting purposes)

I recommend putting the repository under C:/Users/yourPCName for easy access

Need help? Check out GitHub Desktop's official docs!

Visual Studio Code
  1. Go to your Catalyst Guides fork and click <> Code and copy the HTML link.
  2. In VsCode do Ctrl+` to open the Terminal
  3. Type git clone then press space, then paste the link.

Need help? Check out this Geeks for Geeks article!

docs.title: Installing UV and Plugin Dependencies
docs.text:
Install UV
winget install --id=astral-sh.uv  -e

Catalyst Guides has a few Python dependencies that provide additional features for making guides.

Install Dependencies
uv sync

docs.title: Serve (Live Preview)
docs.text:
While you're making your guide, you can preview it by hosting the Catalyst Guides site locally at 127.0.0.1:8000 or localhost:8000. This will also let you know about any warnings or errors that occur during the build process.

uv run mkdocs serve

docs.title: Writing Your Guide
docs.text:
All guides must be Markdown files (.md).

To make a guide, make a new .md file within the docs/ folder. Once created, you can view the new page using Serve.

Check out the formatting guide for every formatting option available to you in Catalyst Guides!

docs.title: Guide Format
docs.text:
Warning

DON'T use Tab to indent a list of authors in the authors section of document headers. It WILL cause syntax errors.

Use a single space instead.

The highlighted lines are required!

exampleGuide.md
---
title: documentName
description: some description
authors:
 - John
 - Jane
 - Bob
---

# Guide Title

Content.

## Second Header

More content.

> modName | [Curseforge](legacy.curseforge link)

docs.title: Making Navigation files (Optional)
docs.text:
If you want to list the pages of your guide in its own order, you can create a .pages file to list an order rather than the default alphabetical order. You can also give pages different names.

Warning

DON'T use Tab to indent a list of pages in .pages files. It WILL cause syntax errors.

Use a single space instead.

The highlighted lines are required!

.pages File Example
nav:
 - index.md
 - about.md

# You can give names to pages
 - Home: index.md
 - About: about.md

# Navigation sub-sections can be created
 - Home: index.md
 - User Guide:
   - Writing your docs: writing-your-docs.md
   - Styling your docs: styling-your-docs.md
 - About:
   - License: license.md
   - Release Notes: release-notes.md

# You MUST put 3 dots at the end of each .pages file
# This will list any pages that aren't defined above
 - ...

docs.title: Build
docs.text:
Before making a Commit, you should build the site which will compile Markdown into HTML.

This should succeed without any warnings or errors before making a commit.

uv run mkdocs build

docs.title: Making a Commit
docs.text: Commiting sends your changes to your fork of Catalyst Guides on GitHub. From there you can then submit a Pull Request.

docs.title: Commit with GitHub Desktop
docs.text:
All changes made will be selected by default, if you do not want to commit some changes, deselect those.

  1. Fill out the Summary and Description on the bottom left, click Commit to main when you're ready to commit.
  2. If you made a mistake, you can undo the commit in the bottom left. Otherwise click Push origin to push the commit to GitHub.

docs.title: Making a Pull Request (PR)
docs.text:
When you submit a PR, you're requesting us to Pull changes from your repository to ours and then deployed on the live Catalyst Guides site.

After making your Commit, go to your fork of Catalyst Guides on GitHub and you'll see a yellow banner with a button that says Compare & pull request.

Click it, then add a Title and what you've changed in the Description, then click Create pull request.

docs.title: More Resources
docs.text:
Most of everything that you need to know is explained on this page or in the Formatting Examples section.

If you have any question, feel free to join the Discord!

  • Markdown Basics
  • Mkdocs Writing Your Docs
  • Material Reference Docs
  • Material PyMdown Extensions
  • PyMdown Extensions Docs

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text:
My header is displaying above the page title.
  • You likely put a Tab indent in your list of authors.
  • Remember, only use a single space when indenting

![](img/faqHeader.png)

My authors are being spelled out letter by letter.
  • You didn't put a space after the hyphen and before the author name.
  • It is - authorName, not -authorName

![](img/faqAuthor.png)

My locally hosted preview won't refresh with changes.
  • Check your PowerShell console output and see if it produces any warning or error. It will tell you exactly what is wrong.
  • Most likely, you have a misspelled file name or you have the incorrect path to an image.

![](img/faqWarning.png)

Catalyst Guides | GitHub | Discord

docs.title: Formatting Examples
docs.text:
These are examples on how to use the various formatting plugins that are available to you in Catalyst Guides.

Most of the references are from their respective plugin documentation pages. I put them all here so you don't have to go easter egg hunting on the various documentation sites.

  • Material References
  • PyMdown Extensions Docs

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
Admonitions follow a simple syntax: !!! followed by a type qualifier, the content is then put on the next line with an indent Tab.

!!! question
    Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Nulla et euismod 
    nulla. Curabitur feugiat, tortor non consequat finibus.

Question

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Nulla et euismod nulla. Curabitur feugiat, tortor non consequat finibus.

docs.title: Changing the Title
docs.text:
You can change the title by adding a quoted string. You can use Markdown in your titles (links, formatting, etc.).

!!! tip "Whatever Title You Want"
    Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit.

Whatever Title You Want

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit.

docs.title: Removing the Title
docs.text:
You can completely remove the title and only render an outline by adding an empty string after !!!

!!! example ""
    Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit.

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit.

docs.title: Collapsible Blocks
docs.text:
You can have a collapsible block using ???. 

??? note
    Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit.
Note

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit.

You can also force the expansion of the block using ???+

???+ note
    Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit.
Note

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit.

docs.title: Nestable Admonitions
docs.text:
You can add admonitions that are nested inside of each other.

Ghdesk Vsc Note Abstract Info Tip Success Question Warning Failure Danger Bug Example

Click me!

docs.title: Annotations
docs.text: You can add little markers called annotations almost anywhere in a document and expand a tooltip containing arbitrary Markdown on click or keyboard focus.

docs.title: Using Annotations
docs.text:
Annotations consist of two parts: a marker (1, 2, 3, etc.), which can be placed anywhere in a block marked with the { .annotate } class, and content located in a list below the block containing the marker

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, (1) consectetur adipiscing elit. 
{ .annotate }

1. :man_raising_hand: I'm an annotation! I can contain `code`, __formatted
    text__, images, ... basically anything that can be expressed in Markdown.

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, (1) consectetur adipiscing elit.

  1. I'm an annotation! I can contain code, formatted text, images, ... basically anything that can be expressed in Markdown.

docs.title: In Annotations
docs.text:
You can nest annotations inside other annotations!

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, (1) consectetur adipiscing elit.
{ .annotate }

1. :man_raising_hand: I'm an annotation! (1)
    { .annotate }

    1. :woman_raising_hand: I'm an annotation as well!

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, (1) consectetur adipiscing elit.

  1. I'm an annotation! (1)

    1. I'm an annotation as well!

docs.title: In Admonitions
docs.text:
You can put annotations within admonitions as well!

!!! note annotate "Title with annotation (1)"

    Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, (2) consectetur adipiscing elit. Nulla et
    euismod nulla. Curabitur feugiat, tortor non consequat finibus, justo
    purus auctor massa, nec semper lorem quam in massa.

1. :man_raising_hand: I'm an annotation in the title!
2. :woman_raising_hand: I'm an annotation as well!

Title with annotation (1)

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, (2) consectetur adipiscing elit. Nulla et euismod nulla. Curabitur feugiat, tortor non consequat finibus, justo purus auctor massa, nec semper lorem quam in massa.

  1. I'm an annotation in the title!
  2. I'm an annotation in the admonition body!

docs.title: In Content Tabs
docs.text:
You can put annotations in content tabs by adding the { .annotate } class to the block of a content tab.

=== "Tab 1"

    Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, (1) consectetur adipiscing elit.
    { .annotate }

    1. :man_raising_hand: I'm an annotation!

=== "Tab 2"

    Phasellus posuere in sem ut cursus (1)
    { .annotate }

    1. :woman_raising_hand: I'm an annotation as well!
Tab 1Tab 2

docs.title: Buttons
docs.text: Material for MkDocs provides dedicated styles for primary and secondary buttons that can be added to any link.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
To render a button, suffix it with the { .md-button } class.

[This is a button!](https://example.com){ .md-button }

This is a button!

docs.title: Adding Primary Buttons
docs.text:
To make a primary button, simply suffix the link with { .md-button .md-button--primary }

[This is a primary button!](https://example.com){ .md-button .md-button--primary }

This is a primary button!

docs.title: Adding Icons to Buttons
docs.text:
You can also use icons to buttons by using icon syntax

[Button with Icon :material-motion-outline:](https://example.com){ .md-button }

Button with Icon

docs.title: Code Blocks
docs.text: Material for MkDocs provides different ways to set up syntax highlighting for code blocks and comes with a copy code button.

docs.title: Code Block Usage
docs.text:
Code block
``` py
import tensorflow as tf
```

import tensorflow as tf

docs.title: Adding a tile
docs.text:
You can add a title to the code block by suffixing title="titleName" after the shortcode.

Code block with title
``` py title="bubble_sort.py"
def bubble_sort(items):
    for i in range(len(items)):
        for j in range(len(items) - 1 - i):
            if items[j] > items[j + 1]:
                items[j], items[j + 1] = items[j + 1], items[j]
```
bubble_sort.py
def bubble_sort(items):
    for i in range(len(items)):
        for j in range(len(items) - 1 - i):
            if items[j] > items[j + 1]:
                items[j], items[j + 1] = items[j + 1], items[j]

docs.title: Adding Line Numbers
docs.text:
Line numbers can be added to a code block by by suffixing linenums="<start>" after the shortcode. <start> represents the starting line number. A code block can start from a line number other than 1.

Code block with line numbers
``` py linenums="1"
def bubble_sort(items):
    for i in range(len(items)):
        for j in range(len(items) - 1 - i):
            if items[j] > items[j + 1]:
                items[j], items[j + 1] = items[j + 1], items[j]
```

def bubble_sort(items):
    for i in range(len(items)):
        for j in range(len(items) - 1 - i):
            if items[j] > items[j + 1]:
                items[j], items[j + 1] = items[j + 1], items[j]

docs.title: Highlighting specific lines
docs.text:
Specific lines can be highlighted by passing the line numbers to the hl_lines argument placed right after the language shortcode. Note that line counts start at 1, regardless of the starting line number specified as part of linenums:

LinesLine ranges

Code block with highlighted lines
``` py hl_lines="1 3"
def bubble_sort(items):
    for i in range(len(items)):
        for j in range(len(items) - 1 - i):
            if items[j] > items[j + 1]:
                items[j], items[j + 1] = items[j + 1], items[j]
```

def bubble_sort(items):
    for i in range(len(items)):
        for j in range(len(items) - 1 - i):
            if items[j] > items[j + 1]:
                items[j], items[j + 1] = items[j + 1], items[j]

Code block with highlighted line range
``` py hl_lines="3-5"
def bubble_sort(items):
    for i in range(len(items)):
        for j in range(len(items) - 1 - i):
            if items[j] > items[j + 1]:
                items[j], items[j + 1] = items[j + 1], items[j]
```

def bubble_sort(items):
    for i in range(len(items)):
        for j in range(len(items) - 1 - i):
            if items[j] > items[j + 1]:
                items[j], items[j + 1] = items[j + 1], items[j]

docs.title: Highlighting inline code blocks
docs.text:
Syntax highlighting can be applied to inline code blocks by prefixing them with a #!, directly followed by the corresponding language shortcode.

Inline code block
The `#!python range()` function is used to generate a sequence of numbers.

The range() function is used to generate a sequence of numbers.

docs.title: Grouping Code Blocks
docs.text:
The most common use of content tabs is to group together code blocks.

=== "C"

    ``` c
    #include <stdio.h>

    int main(void) {
      printf("Hello world!\n");
      return 0;
    }
    ```

=== "C++"

    ``` c++
    #include <iostream>

    int main(void) {
      std::cout << "Hello world!" << std::endl;
      return 0;
    }
    ```
CC++ 
#include <stdio.h>

int main(void) {
  printf("Hello world!\n");
  return 0;
}

#include <iostream>

int main(void) {
  std::cout << "Hello world!" << std::endl;
  return 0;
}

docs.title: Grouping Other Content
docs.text:
You can pretty much put whatever content you want inside a content tab!

=== "Unordered list"
    * Sed sagittis eleifend rutrum
    * Donec vitae suscipit est
    * Nulla tempor lobortis orci

=== "Ordered list"
    1. Sed sagittis eleifend rutrum
    2. Donec vitae suscipit est
    3. Nulla tempor lobortis orci

=== "Some other content"
    Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Nulla et euismod 
    nulla. Curabitur feugiat, tortor non consequat finibus.
Unordered listOrdered listSome other content
  • Sed sagittis eleifend rutrum
  • Donec vitae suscipit est
  • Nulla tempor lobortis orci
  1. Sed sagittis eleifend rutrum
  2. Donec vitae suscipit est
  3. Nulla tempor lobortis orci

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Nulla et euismod nulla. Curabitur feugiat, tortor non consequat finibus.

docs.title: Embedded Content
docs.text:
You can also put content tabs within admonitions!

!!! example
    === "Unordered List"
        * Sed sagittis eleifend rutrum
        * Donec vitae suscipit est
        * Nulla tempor lobortis orci

    === "Ordered List"
        1. Sed sagittis eleifend rutrum
        2. Donec vitae suscipit est
        3. Nulla tempor lobortis orci

Example

Unordered ListOrdered List
  • Sed sagittis eleifend rutrum
  • Donec vitae suscipit est
  • Nulla tempor lobortis orci
  1. Sed sagittis eleifend rutrum
  2. Donec vitae suscipit est
  3. Nulla tempor lobortis orci

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
Data tables can be used at any position in your project documentation and can contain arbitrary Markdown, including inline code blocks, as well as icons and emojis

Data table
| Method      | Description                          |
| ----------- | ------------------------------------ |
| `GET`       | :material-check:     Fetch resource  |
| `PUT`       | :material-check-all: Update resource |
| `DELETE`    | :material-close:     Delete resource |
Method Description GET Fetch resource PUT Update resource DELETE Delete resource

docs.title: Column alignment
docs.text:
If you want to align a specific column to the left, center or right, you can place : characters at the beginning and/or end of the divider.

LeftCenterRight

Data table, columns aligned to left
| Method      | Description                          |
| :---------- | :----------------------------------- |
| `GET`       | :material-check:     Fetch resource  |
| `PUT`       | :material-check-all: Update resource |
| `DELETE`    | :material-close:     Delete resource |
Method Description GET Fetch resource PUT Update resource DELETE Delete resource Data table, columns centered
| Method      | Description                          |
| :---------: | :----------------------------------: |
| `GET`       | :material-check:     Fetch resource  |
| `PUT`       | :material-check-all: Update resource |
| `DELETE`    | :material-close:     Delete resource |
Method Description GET Fetch resource PUT Update resource DELETE Delete resource Data table, columns aligned to right
| Method      | Description                          |
| ----------: | -----------------------------------: |
| `GET`       | :material-check:     Fetch resource  |
| `PUT`       | :material-check-all: Update resource |
| `DELETE`    | :material-close:     Delete resource |
Method Description GET Fetch resource PUT Update resource DELETE Delete resource

docs.title: Adding Hyperlinks
docs.text:
You can add links to other Catalyst Guide pages or to websites using:

You can add links to images as well!

Website links must have the Scheme and Subdomain to work!

[Click to visit Example!](https://www.example.com/)

[How to Contribute!](../README.md)

Click to visit Example!

How to Contribute!

docs.title: Highlighting Changes
docs.text:
Text can be deleted and replacement text added. This can also be combined into onea single operation. Highlighting is also possible and comments can be added inline.

Formatting can also be applied to blocks by putting the opening and closing tags on separate lines and adding new lines between the tags and the content.

docs.title: Highlighting Text
docs.text:
You can highlight text with a simple syntax that's is more convient than usual HTML tags.

==This was marked (highlight)==

^^This was inserted (underline)^^

~~This was deleted (strikethrough)~~

This was marked (highlight)

This was inserted (underline)

This was deleted (strikethrough)

docs.title: Sub and Superscripts
docs.text:
Text can be subscripted (below) or superscripted (above) using simple syntax.

H~2~O

2^X^

H2O

2X

docs.title: Adding keyboard keys
docs.text:
Using the below syntax, you can render keyboard keys and mouse buttons.

You can see shortcodes at Python Markdown Extensions

++ctrl+alt+del++

++print-screen+eject+caps-lock++

++left-button+middle-button+right-button++

Ctrl+Alt+Del

Print Screen+Eject+Caps Lock

Left Button+Middle Button+Right Button

docs.title: Tool Tips
docs.text:
You can add tool tips to text that can contain links if you'd like!

[Hover me](https://example.com "I'm a tooltip!")

Hover me

You can also add tooltips to Icons!

:material-information-outline:{ title="Important information" }

docs.title: Adding Abbreviations
docs.text:
Abbreviations can be defined by using a special syntax, starting with a * and immediately followed by the term or acronym to be associated in square brackets.

Text with abbreviations
The HTML specification is maintained by the W3C.

*[HTML]: Hyper Text Markup Language
*[W3C]: World Wide Web Consortium

The HTML specification is maintained by the W3C.

docs.title: Adding a Glossary
docs.text:
You can add a glossary or footnotes to text that will be displayed at the bottom of the current page and is clickable in both directions.

Nuclear fission[^1] is a reaction in which the nucleus[^2] of an atom splits into two or more smaller nuclei.

[^1]:
    This term will be added to the bottom of the current page and is clickable.
[^2]:
    This is also some term at the bottom of the page.

Nuclear fission1 is a reaction in which the nucleus2 of an atom splits into two or more smaller nuclei.

docs.title: Adding Hidden Comments
docs.text:
You can add comments for other contributors that will be hidden on the live Catalyst site.

<!--- This comment will not be rendered in the final HTML file. --->

<!--- 
This multiline comment will also 
not be rendered in the final HTML file. 
--->

The two comment methods will show in View Source, if you don't want that you can use this format to have truly hidden comments.

[//]: # (This comment will not show in the final HTML or "View Source")

  1. This term will be added to the bottom of the current page and is clickable. ↩

  2. This is also some term at the bottom of the page. ↩

docs.title: Icons and Emojis
docs.text: You can use icons and emojis to enhance your Catalyst Guides!

docs.title: Icons
docs.text:
For icons to work, you must add :material- before the icon shortcode and add a closing colon.

Use Material Design to look up icon shortcodes!

Icons can also have hoverable tooltips!

:material-airplane:

:material-application-braces-outline:

:material-barcode-scan:

docs.title: Emojis
docs.text:
You can use emojis by using shortcodes from the GitHub column of Emojibase between two colons.

:smile:

:no_entry:

docs.title: Image Formatting
docs.text:
You can add images with optional captions using:

The captions show below the image when you click on it.

![optionalCaption](pathToImage.png)

docs.title: Image Resizing
docs.text:
You can resize images using CSS.

![](pathToImage.png){width='300px' height='300px'}

docs.title: Image Alignment
docs.text:
You can align images with .left, .center, or .right. You can add CSS attributes to aligned images as well!

![](pathToImage.png){.left width='100px' height='100px'}

![](pathToImage.png){.center}

![](pathToImage.png){.right}

docs.title: Images with Links
docs.text:
You can add links to images by putting the image syntax within the hyper link syntax.

[![](pathToImage.png)](https://www.example.com/)

docs.title: Dark & Light Mode Images
docs.text:
You can append #only-dark or #only-light to the end of the image path to have different images for dark and light mode of Catalyst Guides.

Click the or in the header to see the example!

![](img/pathToDarkImage.png#only-dark)
![](img/pathToLightImage.png#only-light)

docs.title: Gifs
docs.text:
You add gifs the same way you add images.

![](pathToGif.gif)

docs.title: Videos
docs.text:
You can link mp4 files using:

![type:video](pathToVideo.mp4)

You can also embed YouTube videos using:

https://youtube.com/embed/<videoID>

docs.title: Unordered Lists
docs.text:
- First item
- Second item
- Third item
  • First item
  • Second item
  • Third item

docs.title: Ordered Lists
docs.text:
Ordered lists can be numeral, roman numeral, or alphabetical.

1)  Item 1
2)  Item 2

i.  Item 1
ii. Item 2

a.  Item a
b.  Item b
  1. Item 1
  2. Item 2
  1. Item 1
  2. Item 2
  1. Item a
  2. Item b

docs.title: Custom Ordered Lists
docs.text:
You can also create custom ordered lists by surrounding a numbered list with :

/// fancylists | type=listTypeName start=startPosition
1. List item
2. List item
///
List Type Name Value Decimal 1 Lowercase Alphabetical a Uppercase Alphabetical A Lowercase Roman Numeral i Uppercase Roman Numeral I A lowercase alphabetical list that starts on the 9th letter of the alphabet
/// fancylists | type=a start=9
1. Item i
2. Item j
///
  1. Item i
  2. Item j

docs.title: Different Nested Lists
docs.text:
Number to roman numeral
1) Item 1
2) Item 2
    i. Item 1
    ii. Item 2
  1. Item 1
  2. Item 2
    1. Item 1
    2. Item 2
Unordered to ordered
-   Item 1
-   Item 2
1.  Item 1
2.  Item 2
  • Item 1
  • Item 2
  1. Item 1
  2. Item 2

docs.title: Definition Lists
docs.text:
With definition lists you can define an arbitrary number of key-value pairs such as word/definition or parameters of functions/modules.

`Usurp`

: To seize and hold (office, place, functions, powers, etc.) 
    in possession by force or without right.

    > *Usurp* a throne.

`Intransigent`

: Characterized by refusal to compromise or to abandon an 
often extreme position or attitude.

    > He has remained *intransigent*, refusing all 
    suggestions for improvement of the project.
Usurp

To seize and hold (office, place, functions, powers, etc.) in possession by force or without right.

Usurp a throne.

Intransigent

Characterized by refusal to compromise or to abandon an often extreme position or attitude.

He has remained intransigent, refusing all suggestions for improvement of the project.

docs.title: Task Lists
docs.text:
You can have clickable list items by prefixing unordered list items with [ ] to render an unchecked box or [x] to render a checked box.

- [x] Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit
- [ ] Vestibulum convallis sit amet nisi a tincidunt
    * [x] In hac habitasse platea dictumst
    * [x] In scelerisque nibh non dolor mollis congue sed et metus
    * [ ] Praesent sed risus massa
- [ ] Aenean pretium efficitur erat, donec pharetra, ligula non scelerisque
  • Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit
  • Vestibulum convallis sit amet nisi a tincidunt
    • In hac habitasse platea dictumst
    • In scelerisque nibh non dolor mollis congue sed et metus
    • Praesent sed risus massa
  • Aenean pretium efficitur erat, donec pharetra, ligula non scelerisque

docs.title: Math Formatting
docs.text:
Catalyst Guides uses MathJax to render math equations.

You can use AsciiMath to generate math equations, syntax is available at the bottom of the page.

For the plugin to detect a math equation the $ must be followed by a non-whitespace character and the closing $ must be preceded by a non-whitespace character. This prevents the false positives when using the dollar sign in traditional ways like: I owe Bob $10 and Sally $5.

docs.title: Block Syntax
docs.text:
Block equations must be enclosed with $$...$$ on separate lines.

$$
\cos x=\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\frac{(-1)^k}{(2k)!}x^{2k}
$$
\[ \cos x=\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\frac{(-1)^k}{(2k)!}x^{2k} \]

docs.title: Inline Block Syntax
docs.text:
Inline equations must be enclosed with $...$

The homomorphism $f$ is injective if and only if its kernel is only the
singleton set $e_G$, because otherwise $\exists a,b\in G$ with $a\neq b$ such
that $f(a)=f(b)$.

The homomorphism \(f\) is injective if and only if its kernel is only the singleton set \(e_G\), because otherwise \(\exists a,b\in G\) with \(a\neq b\) such that \(f(a)=f(b)\).

docs.title: Little Bit Large
docs.text:
The Little Bit Large pack sets out to do what every kitchen sink should be doing, but has recently failed to achieve; to take you from the start to end of a Minecraft version with new content added regularly, ensuring you're playing a modpack centered around quality, stability, and multiplayer-based playthroughs.

There will be some custom content in this pack alongside popular mods we all know and love, without gating you unnecessarily along the way.

Refamiliarise yourself with mods such as Mystical Agriculture, Applied Energistics 2 (+Addons), Mekanism, Biomes o' Plenty, and more! As content is released for 1.21.1, it will be added swiftly and seamlessly, all thanks to unification being handled using KubeJS and Almost Unified.

World generation should always be kept simple, yet feel fun to explore and traverse through, which is why we have gone with the fan favourite of Biomes o' Plenty. By sticking with one world generation mod, we can offer a clean, efficient world that will not lag you out when your friends explore deeper into the world. This reiterates our commitment to a quality modpack perfect for playing with friends.

Little Bit Large | CurseForge | GitHub

docs.title: Little Bit Large FAQ
docs.text:
I found a bug, where can I report it?

You can make a bug report on our GitHub!

When will insertModName be added?

You're more than welcome to make a suggestion in the #suggestions channel in our Discord or as an issue with [Suggestion] in the title on our GitHub!

I get an Exit Code 1 while trying to launch the pack!

Exit Code 1 a generic error that could be caused by a wide variety of things. Join our Discord and navigate to #pack-support for more support!

Little Bit Large | CurseForge | GitHub
